Best wishes,

 Von: "Jackson, Andrew" <andrew.jackson@...>
An: archive-crawler@yahoogr=
oups.com 
Gesendet: 11:06 Mittwoch, 6.Februar 2013
Betreff: RE: [archive-cr=
awler] Problem with CSS
 

=C2=A0 
That definitely gets us further=E2=80=A6=

=C2=A0
My guess is that the Wayback redirect warning page is getting in th=
e way. The default Wayback configuration inserts an interstitial page in re=
directs to web pages, so that the user is aware a redirect is happening. Of=
 course, this should not happen for things like CSS, but it seems the site =
you have archived is declaring that redirected CSS URL to be of Content-Typ=
e: text/html. This may be what is confusing Wayback, causing it to insert a=
 web page that displays a message before attempting to perform a browser-si=
de redirect.
=C2=A0
As far as I know, the only way around this is to switch=
 of the interstitial redirect completely and do all redirects on the server=
-side. You can do this by going into your ArchivalUrlReplay.xml file, findi=
ng the bit that says =E2=80=98WARN CLIENT ABOUT PATH REDIRECTS=E2=80=99, an=
d commenting out the XML declaration directly below it (i.e. from <bean =E2=
=80=A6 to </bean>). If you restart Wayback, the interstitials should=C2=A0 =
be gone and, hopefully, so will your playback error.
=C2=A0
Best wishes,
An=
dy Jackson
=C2=A0
From:archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com [mailto:archive-craw=
ler@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Steph
Sent: 06 February 2013 09:39
To: ar=
chive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Problem with C=
SS
=C2=A0
=C2=A0 
Thank you so much for your patience and help.

I installe=
d Firebug and then compared the two lists.

The difference lies within the =
browser requests of the css files.
In the liveweb the server gives a 302 re=
sponse containing the actual location of the file and the browser then requ=
ests this.

In the archived version it gives a 200 Ok response and delivers=
 about 4 kb of data (though the actual files are twice as large). It actual=
ly should give a 302, too!

Does this get us any further?

Steph
=C2=A0
=C2=
=A0

Von:Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...>=

An: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com 
Gesendet: 6:18 Mittwoch, 6.Februar 20=
13
Betreff: Re: [archive-crawler] Problem with CSS
=C2=A0
=C2=A0 
The key m=
ay be to look at exactly what URIs the browser does request, in 
both the '=
live web' and the wayback-replay cases. (Ignore the case where 
you do hand=
-patching for now.)

Two options for collecting such lists are:

(1) the bu=
ilt-in developer tools (or 'Firebug') console of the browser, 
which has a =
'net'/'network' tab that can show all requests

(2) setting the browser to =
go through an intervening logging proxy

When you have lists from both situ=
ations, is there a request the 
wayback-replay visit is not making at all, =
or making and receiving a 
404, compared to the 'live web'?

If so, it's po=
ssible that something uncommon about the page -- in its 
use of relative/de=
clared-BASE URIs, or perhaps in active javascript that 
composes the CSS to=
 request -- prevents the normal Wayback rewriting 
from working.

If the si=
tuation is characterizable, it might be a Wayback bug that can 
be fixed.

=
- Gordon

=3D"color:black;">The key may be to look at exactly what URIs the browser d=
oes request, in <br>both the 'live web' and the wayback-replay cases. (Igno=
re the case where <br>you do hand-patching for now.)<br><br>Two options for=
 collecting
 such lists are:<br><br>(1) the built-in developer tools (or 'F=
irebug') console of the browser, <br>which has a 'net'/'network' tab that c=
an show all requests<br><br>(2) setting the browser to go through an interv=
ening logging proxy<br><br>When you have lists from both situations, is the=
re a request the <br>wayback-replay visit is not making at all, or making a=
nd receiving a <br>404, compared to the 'live web'?<br><br>If so, it's poss=
ible that something uncommon about the page -- in its <br>use of relative/d=
eclared-BASE URIs, or perhaps in active javascript that <br>composes the CS=
S to request -- prevents the normal Wayback rewriting <br>from working.<br>=
<br>If the situation is characterizable, it might be a Wayback bug that can=
 <br>be fixed.<br><br>- Gordon<br><br>On 2/2/13 11:06 AM, Steph wrote:<br>&=
